I used to make fire starters from used road flare remnants.  cut it down to 2 or 3" chunks, tape over the ends with some paper tape, and embed wooden matches in the end.  road flare composition is hot enough to even start wet wood (1450 °C, 2650 °F), and it has a known burn rate. 3" is about 5 minutes of burn time.

The only problem with using flares to start a campfire is you really want to wait a while after the flare is consumed if you want to cook on or with your fire. I had a product called Pyrogel, don't know if they still make it. It was used to preheat the fuel line of backpacking stoves in the winter. Stuff was like a clear napalm. Split a log, chop a shallow 3-4 inch trench in the middle, lay down a ribbon if Pyrogel and you could have a fire going in minutes and the Pyrogel burned off in the same time it took to get the fire established. Safer and faster to cook on.

The reason why the sheet of steel got damaged way easier than the wrench is because they are clearly two different kinds of steel.  The sheet is designed to be reshaped while the wrench is designed to keep it's shape as the wrench is way more hardened overall.
